section.heading: Short Title.
section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the "Baltimore City Open Data Program".

section.heading: Program initiative.
section.text: The Chief Data Officer shall oversee the development and adoption by the City of a program that allows the City to:

para.text: proactively release all publishable data, making it freely available in open formats,
with no restrictons on use or reuse, and fully accessible to the broadest range of users
for varying purposes;
publish high quality, updated data, with documentation and permanence to encourage maximal use;
continue and maintain the "Open Baltimore" Web Portal as the central location for publishable open data;
minimize limitations on the disclosure of public information, while appropriately safeguarding protected and sensitive information; and
encourage innovative uses of the City's publishable data by agencies, the public, and other partners.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Chief Data Officer shall work with the City's agencies and officials to:
identify for each agency a lead open data coordinator who will be responsible for managing that agency's participation in the Open Data Program;
establish a comprehensive inventory of datasets held by each agency and to be published on the Open Data Portal and regularly updated;
develop and implement a process for determining the relative level of risk and public benefit associated with potentially sensitive, non-protected information,
so as to make a determination about whether and how to publish that information;
develop and implement a process for prioritizing the publication of datasets on the Open Data Portal, taking into account:
new and existing signals of interest from the public (such as the frequency of Public Information Act requests);
the City's programmatic priorities;
existing opportunities for data use in the public interest; and
cost;

establish processes for publishing datasets on the Open Data Portal, including processes for ensuring that datasets are reviewed for use-appropriate formats, quality, timeliness, and exclusion of protected and sensitive information;
develop and routinely update a public timeline for new dataset publication; and
ensure that published datasets are available for bulk download.

para.heading: Feedback and collaboration.
para.text: In order to increase and improve use of the City's open data, the Chief Data Officer shall actively encourage agency and public participation by providing regular opportunities for feedback and collaboration.

para.heading: City to maintain.
para.text: The City shall maintain the "Open Baltimore" Web Portal as the Open Data Portal where the City's publishable data will be publicly available.

para.heading: Dataset to be on open license.
para.text: Datasets published on the Open Data Portal shall be available to the public on an open license basis, with no restrictions on copying, publishing, further distributing, modifying, or using the data for any non-commercial or commercial purpose.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On or before June 30 of each year, the Chief Data Officer shall prepare and submit to the Mayor and the City Council an annual Open Data Report.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The report shall include:
an assessment of progress towards achievement of the goals of the Open Data
Program;
an assessment of the current scope of agency compliance;
a list of datasets currently available on the Open Data Portal; and
a description of and publication timeline for datasets envisioned to be published
on the Open Data Portal in the enduing year.

para.heading: Data provided for informational purposes.
para.text: Data is made available on the Open Data Portal for informational purposes only.

The City makes no express or implied warranty as to the completeness, accuracy, content, merchantability, or fitness for any particular use or purpose of any dataset made available on the Open Data Portal

The City is not liable for any deficiency in the completeness, accuracy, content, merchantability, or fitness for any particular use or purpose of any dataset or of any third-party application using a dataset.
Neither this subtitle nor any Open Data Program plan or practice create a private right of action to enforce their provisions.
Failure to comply with this subtitle or any Open Data Program plan or practice does not result in any liability by the City.

para.heading: Display of disclaimers.
para.text: The City shall conspicuously publish on the Open Data Portal the disclaimers contained in subsections (a) through (c) of this section.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Agency.
para.text: "Agency" means any department, board, commission, council, authority, committee, office, or other unit of City government in either the executive or legislative branches, including all elected officials.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Non-permanent record" means a public record with temporary value that may be destroyed after the passage of a specified period of time.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Non-permanent record" includes:
extra copies of documents that:
have no separate administrative purpose or value; and
are preserved only for convenience or reference;
informational copies of correspondence, directives, forms, or other similar documents on which no administrative action is recorded or taken;
library and museum materials made or acquired for reference or exhibition purposes;
personal papers or papers of a private or non-official character that pertain to an individual's private affairs;
duplicate copies of documents maintained in the same file;
extra copies of printed or processed materials for which complete record sets exists, including current and superceded manuals maintained outside the agency responsible for maintaining the manual;
catalogs, trade journals, and other publications received from government agencies, commercial firms, or private institutions that require no further action by the agency; or
physical exhibits, artifacts, and other material objects lacking evidential value.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Record" means any documentary material in any form created or received by an agency in connection with the transaction of public business.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Record" includes:
written materials, email, books, photographs, photocopies, publications, forms, microfilms, tapes, computerized records, maps, drawings, and other materials in any format;
data generated, stored, received, or communicated by electronic means for use by, or storage in, an information system or for transmission from one information system to another; and
non-permanent records.

para.heading: Record inventory.
para.text: "Record inventory" means a survey of all records series maintained by an agency resulting in a detailed, itemized compilation of the records in the possession of that agency.

para.heading: Retention period.
para.text: "Retention period" means the period of time that a record must be retained in accordance with an approved Records Retention and Disposition Schedule.

para.heading: State Archivist.
para.text: "State Archivist" means the individual appointed under Maryland State Government Article, § 9-1005, or that individual's designee.

section.heading: City Records Management Officer: In general.
section.text: There is a City Records Management Officer appointed by the Director of the Department of Legislative Reference.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The City Records Management Officer shall direct the development and administration of a continuing records management, archival, and disposal program for the records of all City agencies.

para.heading: Specific duties.
para.text: The City Records Management Officer must:
establish standards, procedures, and techniques for the effective management of City records;
prepare, for the approval of the State Archivist, Record Retention and Disposition Schedules providing for:
the retention of City and agency records of continuing value for a specific retention period;
the orderly disposal of City and agency records no longer possessing sufficient administrative, legal, fiscal, or historical value to warrant further preservation; and
the identification and preservation of records no longer needed
by an agency that are of historical significance;
review all proposals for the digitization of records, whether or not the ultimate destruction of the original record is involved;
assist agency heads in the preparation of agency record inventories;
periodically inspect records and records management practices of agencies; and
organize and administer a City records storage center or centers for the City's inactive and historical records.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the City Records Management Officer must adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of this subsection to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Duties of agencies.
section.text: Each agency head must:

para.text: designate an Agency Records Officer to:
serve as the agency liaison to the City Records Management officer;
and
assist the City Records Management Officer in carrying out the records management program for the agency;
on the request of the City Records Management Officer, prepare a record inventory;
cooperate with the City Records Management Officer in the preparation of Record Retention and Disposition Schedules for the agency head's agency; and
comply with the rules and regulations adopted by the City Records Management Officer with respect to the retention, disposal, storage, and digitization of agency records.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: Nothing in this section applies to any record that has been transferred to the custody of the Maryland State Archives.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in this section or in an approved Record Retention and Disposition Schedule, records created or received by an agency in the course of official City business are the property of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore and may not be destroyed, sold, transferred, or otherwise disposed of.

para.heading: Agency compliance.
para.text: Each agency must comply with its Record Retention and Disposition Schedule and the disposal process set forth in Title 10, Subtitle 6 of the State Government Article of the Maryland Code to ensure:
the orderly retention of records required for the operation of the agency; and
the prompt disposal of records having no further value.
An agency head must submit a Certificate of Disposal to the City Records Management Officer for any record disposed of in accordance with the agency's Record Retention and Disposition Schedule.
The Certificate of Disposal required by this section must set forth a list of the disposed records and a certification that the records were disposed of in accordance with this subtitle.
The City Records Management Officer shall transmit a copy of any Certificate of Disposal received under this subsection to the State Archivist.

para.heading: Disposal of records held at a records storage center.

para.text: At least 30 days before any records held at any City records storage center administered under this subtitle are destroyed, a list of the records proposed for destruction must be submitted to the City Solicitor and the City Auditor for review.

At any time during the 30-day review period, the City Solicitor or the City Auditor may submit to the City Records Management Officer a written objection to the destruction of a record or set of records on the list.
On receipt of a written objection under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the City Records Management Officer must retain the record.

section.heading: Digitization.
section.text: As provided in City Charter Article I, § 7(b), any agency may substitute a digital image or file for any of its records, provided that:

para.text: the required Record Retention and Disposition Schedule has been approved; and
any digital surrogates have been produced in a manner consistent with the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

section.heading: Bureau established.
section.text: A Central Bureau of Investigation is hereby created in the Law Department under the City Solicitor.

para.heading: Claims against or by City.
para.text: It shall be the duty of the Central Bureau of Investigation, to investigate:
any and all claims made by third persons against the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore;
all claims which the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore may have against third persons; and
all reports made by any department, board, bureau, commission, agency, or employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore of an accidental injury suffered by any employee thereof.

para.heading: Workers' Compensation claims.
para.text: The Central Bureau of Investigation shall also, at the direction of the City Solicitor, or at the direction of an Assistant City Solicitor handling Workmen's Compensation claims, investigate all claims for Workmen's Compensation filed with the State Workers' Compensation Commission by any employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: Investigations directed by Solicitor.
para.text: The Central Bureau of Investigation shall also:
make any and all investigations, of whatsoever kind or character, directed to be made by the City Solicitor; and
report the results of any and all investigations made by it to the City Solicitor.

para.heading: Reports to Division of Disability Compensation.
para.text: The Central Bureau of Investigation shall send to the Division of Disability Compensation of the Central Payroll Bureau, a summary of any report of any investigation of any claim filed with the State Workers' Compensation Commission by any employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore for Workmen's Compensation.
The City Solicitor shall appoint the employees of the Central Bureau of Investigation in accordance with the City Charter.
The employees shall be compensated as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.
All non-lawyer positions in the Central Bureau of Investigation are part of the Classified Service of the City of Baltimore, subject to the laws, rules, and regulations governing that service.

All appointments to fill vacancies in non-lawyer positions caused by death, resignation, dismissal, retirement, or other reason shall be made by the City Solicitor from eligible lists established by the Department of Human Resources.

para.heading: Specialists for special purposes.
para.text: The City Solicitor may from time to time engage for special purposes the services of experts and specialists for any particular case or cases.

section.heading: Report of injury or damage.
section.text: Every department, board, bureau, commission, officer, and employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore (except the Bureau of Receipts and the employees thereof, so far as claims for taxes are concerned) shall immediately, upon the happening of any accidental injury to any employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, and upon the filing of, or knowledge of the existence of, any claim against the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, or any injury or damage caused to the person or property of any third person by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, and any claim of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore against third parties for any damage to property owned by or under the control of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, or any other injury or damage for which the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore may have a claim against third parties, whether arising by subrogation or otherwise, report the happening of such accidental injury or damage, or the filing or knowledge of any such claim or damage, with the Central Bureau of Investigation, so that an immediate investigation of all such accidental injuries and all such claims and damages may be forthwith made by the Central Bureau of Investigation.

section.heading: Inconsistent laws.
section.text: In the event of any inconsistency between this subtitle and the terms and provisions of any ordinance of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, the terms and provisions of any other such ordinance are repealed to the extent of such inconsistency.

para.heading: Convention Complex created; Director.
para.text: There shall be a Convention Complex, consisting of the Baltimore Arena and the Convention Center, the head of which shall be a Convention Complex Director, who shall be appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the Baltimore City Charter.

para.heading: Managers.
para.text: There shall also be a Baltimore Arena Manager who shall manage and operate the Baltimore Arena, and a Convention Center Manager who shall manage and operate the Convention Center, both of whom shall be subject to the supervision and control of the Convention Complex Director.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: The compensation of the Director and Managers and their assistants, aides, and employees shall be subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates and shall be paid as provided in the annual Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Convention Complex Director shall have the following powers, which may be delegated by him to the Convention Center Manager or the Baltimore Arena Manager:

with the prior approval of the Board of Estimates, to contract with consulting, planning, or designing engineers or architects, advertising or promotional agencies, and any other persons possessing technical or specialized skills in connection with the requirements of the Convention Center or Baltimore Arena;

within a framework submitted to and approved by the Board of Estimates, to establish fees, rentals, or charges for the use or occupancy of the Convention Center and Baltimore Arena, or any part thereof, and to collect such fees, rentals, or charges; all such collections shall be remitted to the Director of Finance of Baltimore City;

to adopt, promulgate, and enforce rules and regulations for the management, use, occupancy, government, and preservation of order with respect to all land, property, facilities, and activities under his supervision or control, and a copy of all such rules and regulations shall be effective 10 days after they are filed with the Department of Legislative Reference of Baltimore; and any and all rules and regulations previously adopted by the Civic Center Commission shall remain in force and effect until superseding rules and regulations are adopted and promulgated by the Convention Complex Director; and

to do any and all things necessary, proper, or expedient relative to or in connection with the use, occupancy, control, operation, management, promotion, maintenance, and repair of the Convention Center and Baltimore Arena.

para.heading: Penalties for violating rule or regulation.
para.text: Every person who violates any such rules or regulations so adopted or promulgated shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof in any court of competent jurisdiction, shall be fined not more than $500 for each and every offense or imprisonment for not more than 12 months.

para.heading: Contracts subject to Charter.
para.text: All contracts or agreements entered into for or in connection with the maintenance or repair of the Convention Center and Baltimore Arena and their facilities shall be subject to the terms and provisions of Article VI, § 11 of the City Charter, as they now exist or as they may hereafter be amended.

para.heading: Title to property.
para.text: The title to all land or property of every kind and every right, interest, franchise, easement or privilege therein, acquired for or in connection with the Convention Center and Baltimore Arena shall be or remain in the name of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

container.heading: Commission on the Aging and Retirement Education

para.text: It is the intent of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore in the reordination of this subtitle to create an agency which will better serve to coordinate governmental programs and develop the public and private resources needed to enable the elderly to remain full participants in the community after retirement.

The increasing complexity of the problems faced by the elderly requires a broadly based, comprehensive approach to deal with matters of finance, organization, social service, education, housing, employment, leisure time activity, medical service, and transportation.
By the provisions of this subtitle, the Mayor and City Council focuses on these issues as they relate specifically to the elderly.

It is intended that the agency hereby created will result in increased input which will flow from its composition and from the status of its executive director as an officer of the Mayor and City Council and from the new orientation and scope of the agency's powers and responsibilities as further provided in this subtitle.

section.heading: Commission established.
section.text: There is hereby created a Commission to be known as the Baltimore Commission on the Aging and Retirement Education .

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commission shall consist of 24 members, 18 of whom are appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the Baltimore City Charter, and 6 of whom are ex-officio members.

para.heading: Appointed members.
para.text: Of the 18 members to be appointed by the Mayor:
at least 4 shall be over 65 years of age and retired;
2 shall be selected to represent the pre-retirement aspects of the Commission's work;
1 shall be a member of the City Council;
1 shall be a member from Baltimore City of the Medical and Chirurgical Faculty of Maryland;
1 shall be a member of the Baltimore City Medical Society;
1 shall be a member of organized labor;
1 shall represent industry;
2 shall be associated with voluntary organizations which provide services to the elderly; and
5 shall be selected because of their general interest in providing services to the elderly.

para.heading: Ex officio members.
para.text: The 6 ex officio members of the Commission are the following, or their designated representatives:
the Commissioner of Health;
the Director of the Department of Social Services;
the Director of the Department of Planning;
the Police Commissioner;
the Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development; and
the Director of the Department of Recreation and Parks.
The appointed members, other than the member of the City Council, serve terms of 4 years concurrent with the Mayor's term of office.
The appointee who is a member of the City Council serves for a term expiring upon the expiration of his current term in the City Council.

para.heading: Chair.
para.text: The Mayor shall designate 1 of the appointed members to be the Chair of the Commission.

para.heading: Vacancies.
para.text: On a vacancy in the membership of the Commission, the member appointed by the Mayor to fill the vacancy must meet the same qualifications for appointment as the member being succeeded and serves for the remainder of the unexpired term.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: The members of the Commission shall receive no compensation for their services on the Commission but shall be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.

para.heading: Attendance at meetings.
para.text: Any appointed member of the Commission who fails to attend 4 consecutive meetings without good cause as determined by the Mayor shall be deemed to have resigned.

The Mayor shall appoint a properly qualified person as Executive Director of the Commission, to be an officer of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the Baltimore City Charter for a term of 4 years, provided, however, that the first such term shall last until December 31, 1976.
The Executive Director thus appointed shall receive such salary as may be provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Staff and budget.
para.text: The Executive Director shall be authorized to:
employ such assistants as shall be necessary to carry out his duties, who shall be members of the classified service, and
expend such funds as may be provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commission is charged with the responsibility for assisting City agencies and departments in the coordination of an effective program of services to and opportunities for the elderly.

para.heading: Specific duties.
para.text: This shall include:
the coordination of existing City programs;
the recommendation of new programs;
the evaluation of current programs and proposed legislation to determine their impact on the elderly; and
the identification of federal and state funding for City programs to meet the needs of the elderly.

para.heading: Report on findings.
para.text: The Commission shall promptly report to the Mayor on its findings concerning the programs and policies of the Mayor and City Council as reflected in:
the Ordinance of Estimates;
other ordinances; or
administrative policies of municipal agencies.

para.heading: Hearings and studies.
para.text: The Commission shall hold hearings and undertake surveys and studies as appropriate to:
evaluate existing municipal programs for the elderly; and
make recommendations for their improvement to the Mayor.

para.heading: Evaluation of how information is disseminated.
para.text: The Commission shall:
evaluate the methods by which information concerning available municipal programs for the elderly is disseminated; and
make recommendations to the Mayor of means to improve such methods of dissemination.

para.heading: Representing City.
para.text: The Commission shall act as a representative of the Mayor and City Council in dealing with the private sector and with other governments in an effort to develop additional public and private resources to provide better programs for the elderly.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: The Commission shall render an annual report to the Mayor on its activities.

para.heading: Authorized.
para.text: Upon the payment and full satisfaction of any loan heretofore or hereafter made by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore for Off-Street Parking Projects, as authorized under Article II, § (20) of the City Charter and property is conveyed to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore to secure the repayment of the same, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore with the approval of the Board of Estimates of Baltimore City is hereby authorized and empowered to execute and deliver to the owner or owners a release, a conveyance, or reconveyance of the land with the improvements thereon so conveyed to the City of Baltimore to secure said loan.

para.heading: Solicitor's approval required.
para.text: No deed or releases shall pass in accordance herewith unless the same shall first have been approved by the City Solicitor.

section.heading: Notice of meetings.
section.text: The Planning Commission shall give to each member of the City Council in writing, delivered by mail or in person by the Friday preceding any Tuesday meeting, or by the 4th day preceding any other meeting, an agenda of all matters which the Planning Commission proposes to consider with respect to altering or amending the master plan of the City of Baltimore.

section.heading: Fee for examination of subdivision plan.

para.heading: Fee authorized.
para.text: The Department of Planning, with the approval of the City Council of Baltimore, may establish and impose charges for subdivision plans, as defined in Article VII, § 76 of the City Charter, submitted to the Planning Commission for examination and action by it, to defray the cost and expenses incident to said examination and action.
Said charge shall be paid at the time a subdivision plan is first filed with the Department of Planning in the usual course of business.
Payment may be made either in cash or by certified check made payable to the Director of Finance of Baltimore.

para.heading: Fee non-refundable.
para.text: Said charge shall not be refunded in whole or in part, under any circumstances.

para.heading: Enumerated.
para.text: The Department of Public Works comprises the following Bureaus:
Bureau of Solid Waste; and
Bureau of Water and Wastewater.

para.heading: Continued powers and duties.
para.text: All of the rights, powers, duties, obligations, and functions previously conferred or imposed on these Bureaus and their Bureau Heads shall continue to be exercised and performed by these Bureaus and Bureau heads unless otherwise assigned or reassigned by law or as provided in this subtitle.
The Director of Public Works is responsible for the proper conduct, management, and operation of the Bureaus established under this subtitle.

All of the rights, powers, duties, obligations, and functions that are now or may subsequently be conferred or imposed on any of the Bureaus or Heads of Bureaus of the Department of Public Works shall be exercised and performed by the Bureaus or by their respective Heads subject to the control, direction, and supervision of the Director of Public Works.

In the event of any duplication of authority or responsibility between any 2 or more Bureaus established under this subtitle, the Director of Public Works has the right and power to determine which 1 or more of the Bureaus involved will carry out the performance of that authority or responsibility.

Subject to the authority of the Board of Estimates, the Director of Public Works has have the power and authority from time to time to assign and reassign among the Bureaus of the Department of Public Works the performance of any duties and the exercise of any powers that are imposed or conferred on the Department.
Subject to the approval of Board of Estimates, the Director of Public Works has the power and authority from time to time to rename the various Bureaus of the Department.

para.heading: Transfer of powers from abolished bureaus.
para.text: Subject to the limitations provided in Ordinance 15-435, Section 2 {"Transfer of powers from DPW to DHCD"}, all the authorities, powers, responsibilities, rights, and duties previously imposed or conferred on any former Bureau or Bureau Head of the Department of Public Works are imposed and conferred on the Director of Public Works, and, subject to the authority of the Board of Estimates, all those authorities, powers, responsibilities, rights, and duties may be delegated by the Director to whichever Bureau or Bureau Head in the Department that the Director directs.

annotations.annotation: Ord. 15-435 repealed §§ 17-3 through 17-7, which described no-longer extant Bureaus, and renumbered § 17-8 to be § 17-3.

section.heading: Appointment of Bureau Heads and Assistant Bureau Heads.

para.heading: Director to designate Assistant Head positions.
para.text: The Director of Public Works may designate the positions of Assistant Bureau Heads for each of the Bureaus of the Department of Public Works.

text.em: Mayor to appoint Heads and Assistant Heads.

para.text: All Bureau Heads and Assistant Bureau Heads shall be appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Charter Article IV, § 6.

section.heading: Office of Disaster Control and Civil Defense.

para.heading: Office created.
para.text: There is hereby created the "Office of Disaster Control and Civil Defense" for Baltimore City.

para.heading: Functions transferred.
para.text: The function and duties of the Civil Defense Division of the Fire Department, as set forth in said Ordinance 63-042, are hereby transferred to the said new Office.

para.heading: Designation of initial Director.
para.text: The Director of said Office initially shall be the same person who is, at the time of the passage of this ordinance, Director of the Civil Defense Division of the Fire Department; and also the same person appointed as Civil Defense Director of Baltimore City by the Governor, upon recommendation of the Mayor of said City, as provided by Article 16A, § 7 of the Maryland Code.

He shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, and operation of such Office, subject to the direction and control of the Mayor of Baltimore, under the general power of the Governor.
Said Director shall be responsible for the organization, administration, and operation of a disaster control and civil defense program, which program shall include a Civil Defense Volunteer Corps.

para.heading: Director to appoint.
para.text: The Director shall appoint such assistants, aides, and employees as may be necessary to carry out a disaster control and civil defense program and also the State Civil Defense Plans and Programs, such employees to be subject to the provisions of City classified service, as provided by Article VII, §§ 94 through 104 of the City Charter.

para.heading: Personnel transferred.
para.text: The personnel now employed by the Civil Defense Division of the Fire Department are hereby transferred to the Office of Disaster Control and Civil Defense of Baltimore City, without diminution or loss of any rights or privileges heretofore earned or obtained by them.

para.heading: Additional personnel.
para.text: Any additional employees of this Office who may be required in an expanded program shall be as provided in the annual Ordinance of Estimates or as provided by the Board of Estimates.

The Civil Defense Division of the Fire Department, on or about July 1, 1968, shall transfer to the Office of Disaster Control and Civil Defense any and all property which it now has in its custody or under its control used or usable in civil defense and disaster control work.
Thereafter, the said Office:
shall become the custodian thereof, charged with the responsibility of maintaining and keeping all such property in good order and repair; and
shall keep such records of same as are required by law.

para.heading: Additional property.
para.text: Additional property or equipment required to carry out the purposes of this subtitle shall be obtained by said Office as provided in the annual Ordinance of Estimates or as approved by the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Office created.
para.text: There is created the Office of Intergovernmental Research under a Director.

para.heading: Function.
para.text: It is the function of this Office to analyze the State and Federal legislative needs of the City and related matters and make recommendations thereon to the Mayor.

para.heading: Appointment.
para.text: The Director of the Office of Intergovernmental Research shall be chosen by the Mayor from a list of possibilities provided from time to time by the Civil Service Commission.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: The Director:
shall serve during good behavior for a term not to exceed the term of the appointing authority;
shall be subject to removal only after charges are preferred by the Mayor and a full hearing is had before the Civil Service Commission; and
shall be discharged only upon proof of inefficiency, neglect of duty, or misconduct in office.
The Director's successor shall be chosen in the same manner.
From time to time, as there is a vacancy, the Mayor shall choose and appoint the Director of the Office of Intergovernmental Research in the same manner.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: The Director of the Office of Intergovernmental Research shall be a person who has had responsible prior experience in:
legislative analysis; and
subjects relating generally to government, public policy, fiscal policy, law, or political science.

The Director shall devote full time to performing and carrying out the duties and assignments of the Office of Intergovernmental Research, as set forth in this subtitle and as may otherwise be assigned.

And subject to the provisions of this subtitle, the Director shall not hold any other municipal office or position or perform any of the duties or responsibilities conferred upon another municipal officer by Charter or ordinance.

para.heading: Director to employ staff.
para.text: The Director of the Office of Intergovernmental Research is empowered to employ such personnel as may be deemed necessary in order to perform the duties and exercise the powers conferred by this subtitle upon the Office of Intergovernmental Research, and as may be provided from time to time in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Supplies.
para.text: The Office of Intergovernmental Research shall be supplied with all necessary books, maps, charts, stationery, and all appliances and incidentals necessary for the proper discharge of its duties, to be paid from funds supplied in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Agencies to assist Office.
para.text: Every department, bureau, or other agency of the municipal government, upon request, shall provide reasonable assistance and information to the Office of Intergovernmental Research.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Baltimore City Commission for Women.

para.heading: Voting members.
para.text: The Commission comprises 19 voting members, to be appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Mayor may appoint 1 or more members of the Baltimore City Council or the Baltimore City delegation to the Maryland General Assembly as additional, non-voting members of the Commission.

para.heading: Ex-officio members.
para.text: Notwithstanding subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, any female member of the City Council shall be an ex-officio, non-voting member of the Commission.

para.heading: Office of Equity and Civil Rights member.
para.text: The Mayor shall appoint a representative from the Baltimore City Office of Equity and Civil Rights or its successor agency to be a non-voting member of the Commission.

para.heading: Appointment without regard to political affiliation.
para.text: The appointment of members must be made without regard to political affiliation.
Members serve for a term of 4 years, concurrent with the terms of the Mayor and the City Council.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Commission:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Vacancies.
para.text: A member appointed to fill a vacancy in an unexpired term or to succeed a member who is holding over serves only for the remainder of that term.
The Mayor shall designate a member of the Commission to serve as its Chair.
Members of the Commission may select any other officers they consider necessary or appropriate.

para.heading: Committees.
para.text: The Chair may appoint committees to assist the Commission in carrying out its functions and duties.
The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chair as frequently as required to perform its duties.
A majority of the voting members of the Commission constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business.
An affirmative vote by the majority of a quorum is needed for any official action.

para.heading: Rules of procedure.
para.text: The Commission may adopt rules of procedure to govern its meetings and procedures.

para.heading: Failure to attend meetings.
para.text: If any member is absent from regularly scheduled meetings more than 3 times in 1 year, not counting absences excused by the Chair:
the member is considered to have resigned; and
the Chair shall request that member's appointing authority to fill the resultant vacancy.
The Commission may appoint a properly qualified person as Executive Director of the Commission.
The Executive Director is entitled to a salary as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.
The Executive Director shall perform the duties that the Commission prescribes.
The Executive Director may employ a staff as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.
Staff members shall be members of the classified service.

para.heading: Volunteers.
para.text: The Commission may engage the services of volunteer workers and consultants, without salary, as it considers necessary from time to time.

para.heading: Budget.
para.text: The Director may expend funds as authorized in the Ordinance of Estimates or in any supplemental appropriations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Baltimore City Commission for Women shall undertake the activities described in this section.

para.heading: Referral system.
para.text: The Commission shall:
develop an information and referral system for all services in the City related to women; and
recommend other services when a need for them is determined.

para.heading: Forum for amelioration.
para.text: The Commission shall serve as the focus and forum for the identification and amelioration of the unique problems faced by women in our society and on any practice of discrimination or prejudice that exists because of gender.
The Commission shall:
conduct research, policy analysis, and public information and education programs and activities to assist in addressing the needs of women; and
institute and conduct other programs, meetings, and conferences to promote equal rights and opportunities for all women.

These programs and activities shall address the special needs of women related to race, age, national origin, religious preference, disability, sexual preference, physical characteristics, marital status, reproductive health, and economic status.

para.heading: Monitor workforce.
para.text: The Commission shall:
review and monitor the conditions of women in the workforce in Baltimore City;
make recommendations promoting equal pay for work of equal value and equitable representation by women in all job levels; and
direct attention to the problems facing women in the workforce.

para.heading: Advise and counsel.
para.text: The Commission shall:

advise and counsel the residents of Baltimore City, the City Council, the Mayor, and the various departments and agencies of the City, state, and federal governments on all matters involving women's lives; and
recommend programs and legislation it considers necessary and proper to promote and ensure equal rights, equal opportunities, and equal access to services for all persons regardless of gender.

para.heading: Evaluate policies and programs.
para.text: The Commission shall review and evaluate the impact of existing and proposed policies and programs and legislation affecting women.

para.heading: Seeking to remove inequalities.
para.text: The Commission shall work to remove inequalities due to discrimination or prejudice on the basis of gender in housing, recreation, employment, education, community services, criminal justice, financing, credit, insurance, and related matters.

para.heading: Monitor board and commissions.
para.text: The Commission shall monitor City government so as to ensure the equitable representation of women on all City boards and commissions.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, the following terms shall have the meanings listed below.

para.heading: Area.
para.text: An "area" shall mean an area consisting of more than 1 block.

para.heading: Block.
para.text: A "block" shall mean all of the properties on both sides of a given street existing between 2 consecutive intersecting streets.

para.heading: Household.
para.text: "Household" shall mean all persons occupying a single housing unit (i.e. {sic} house, apartment, group of rooms, or single room intended for occupancy as separate living quarters).

para.heading: Neighborhood Block Watch block or area.
para.text: "Neighborhood Block Watch block or area" shall mean a block or an area designated in an application filed pursuant to § 21-3 in which signs provided for in this subtitle may be erected.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore finds and declares that the threat, fear, and intimidation caused by the criminal element is one of the most compelling problems facing society today. Crime isolates people in their own homes, causing them to become suspicious of, and in some cases afraid of, their neighbors. And yet, law enforcement officials tell us that neighborhoods with little inter-residential communication are more vulnerable to crime than are those in which neighbors communicate and cooperate with each other on a regular basis.

para.heading: New program.
para.text: A new kind of anti-crime program starting to take hold in neighborhoods around the City seeks to promote communication and cooperation among neighbors as an effective countermeasure to crime. This subtitle sets up a program to install signs in those neighborhoods where a Neighborhood Block Watch Program is in effect.

para.heading: Liberal construction.
para.text: This subtitle should be liberally interpreted to achieve its anti-crime goals.

para.heading: Program established.
para.text: There is established a Neighborhood Block Watch Sign Program to promote an anti-crime posture in neighborhoods and between the neighborhoods and City officials.

para.heading: Available to qualified blocks and areas.

para.text: The Program shall be available to all qualified residential blocks and areas of the City.

In order to qualify for the Program, such blocks and areas shall meet the criteria set forth in this subtitle and any rules and regulations established by the Police Commissioner in consultation with the Director of Transportation and the Director of Finance under the requirements of this subtitle.

para.heading: Procedure to qualify.
para.text: This procedure shall be as follows:

In order to be considered for the Neighborhood Block Watch Sign Program, a neighborhood group, group of residents, or community association shall submit an application through the Police Commissioner to the Director of Transportation indicating the collective desire of at least 60% of the households in the block or area to have signs placed.
The boundary of the block and area within the Neighborhood Block Watch block or area shall be clearly identified on the application.

Upon receipt of a valid application, the Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Director of Transportation, shall review the block or area identified and any other information required by the Police Commissioner necessary to the completion of the application.
The Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Director of Transportation, shall approve or deny the application.
When an application is denied, the Police Commissioner or his designee shall state the reasons for the denial.
The Director of Transportation shall authorize the installation of Neighborhood Block Watch Signs in the block or area from which the application was approved.

section.heading: Signs.
section.text: The neighborhood group, group of residents, or community association which has received approval for the installation of the Neighborhood Block Watch sign shall purchase signs approved by the Police Commissioner and all other material necessary to the installation of the signs. The signs shall be installed by the Department of Transportation. Any person(s) or organizations may volunteer to pay the fee.

section.heading: Administration of program.
section.text: The Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Director of Transportation and the Director of Finance, shall promulgate rules necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle. The Police Commissioner shall also administer the program.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Children.
para.text: "Children" means individuals under the age of 14 years.

para.heading: Commission.
para.text: "Commission" means the Baltimore City Youth Commission.

para.heading: Office.
para.text: "Office" means the Office of Children and Family Success.

para.heading: Task Force.
para.text: "Task Force" means the Baltimore City Trauma-Informed Care Task Force.

para.heading: Youth.
para.text: "Youth" means an individual between the ages of 14 and 25, inclusive.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of this Part II is to allow youth the opportunity to provide advice, recommendations, and information for the Mayor, the City Council, and municipal agencies on the development of coordinated community and government policies, programs, and services that support children, youth, and their families.

section.heading: Commission established.
section.text: There is a Baltimore City Youth Commission.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commission comprises 17 voting members and 14 non-voting members.
The voting members shall be appointed by the Mayor, in accordance with City Charter Article IV, § 6, as follows:
1 youth from each of the 14 Council Districts, at least 1 of whom is not a graduate of or then enrolled in a traditional educational program; and
3 at-large youths recommended by the President of the City Council.
Each voting member of the Commission must be a resident of Baltimore City.
A youth may not be appointed to a term as a voting member of the Commission if that youth would become 26 years old during that term.

para.heading: Agency representatives.
para.text: Each of the following entities shall designate a non-voting member to represent that entity:
Baltimore City Public School System.
Department of Recreation and Parks.
Health Department.
Police Department (PAL Centers).
Department of Social Services.
State's Attorney's Office.
Enoch Pratt Free Library.
Mayor's Office of Employment Development.
Housing Authority of Baltimore City.
State Department of Juvenile Services.
Family League of Baltimore City.
Baltimore City Community College.
2 non-voting, ex officio members are:
the Mayor; and
the President of the City Council.
The Mayor or Council President may designate another person to serve in her or his place.
The term of a voting member expires at the end of the Mayor's term.
At the end of a term, a voting member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Commission:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.
The Mayor shall designate a voting member to serve as Commission Chair.
The Chair may select other officers.
The Chair may appoint committees to assist the Commission in carrying out its functions and duties.
The Commission shall meet on the call of the Chair as frequently as required to perform its duties, but not less than 6 times nor more than 10 times each year.
A majority of the voting members constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business.
An affirmative vote of at least a majority of a quorum is needed for any official action.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commission may adopt rules and regulations to govern its meetings and operations.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed the text of this subsection to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Commission duties.
section.text: The Commission shall:

para.text: develop and maintain a 3-year plan of action that outlines specific areas for Commission study and recommendations;
review issues relating to programs and services for children and youth;
identify and recommend priorities among programs and services for children and youth;
create a forum for discussions with children, youth, and their families;
advocate services and programs for children and youth;
make recommendations for programs, policies, procedures, or legislation it deems necessary to promote the well-being of children, youth, and their families;
work with the public and private sector in a collaborative effort to:
bring forth the concerns of children and youth; and
evaluate and strengthen programming that will enhance the interpersonal and social development of children and youth;
develop a communications network to share information about public and private services to children and youth;
submit an annual report to the Mayor and the City Council; and
perform any other duties that the Mayor requests.

container.heading: Office of Children and Family Success

section.heading: Office established.
section.text: There is an Office of Children and Family Success in the Office of the Mayor.

section.heading: Director – appointment.
section.text: The Director of the Office is appointed by the Mayor in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.

section.heading: Director – powers and duties.
section.text: The Director shall:

para.text: identify the needs of children and youth according to age, location, and special services required;
identify public and private services available to children, youth, and families;
identify changes in public policy, service delivery, and funding necessary to improve the services available to children, youth, and families;
serve as a community voice for children and youth;
develop and implement programs to benefit children and youth;
provide staff and serve as advisor to the Commission;
serve as ex-officio member and advisor to the Task Force;
generally promote the well-being of all children and youth of Baltimore City;

be represented on any other special committee or task force that considers matters relating to children and youth, and work with the various boards, commissions, and municipal agencies that interact with the Office as deemed appropriate;
perform such other duties as required by the Mayor; and
review proposed legislation referred to the Office by the City Council, assessing its probable effect on the physical, social, emotional, and intellectual welfare of the children of this City.

para.heading: Staff.
para.text: The Office may employ staff in accordance with the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Budget.
para.text: The Office may expend funds authorized in the Ordinance of Estimates or any supplemental appropriations.

section.heading: Trauma-informed care initiative.
section.text: In addition to any other duties set forth in this subtitle, it is the duty of the Office to coordinate a citywide initiative to prioritize the trauma-responsive and trauma-informed delivery of city services impacting children, youth, and families.

section.heading: Trauma-Informed Care Task Force – Established.
section.text: There is a Baltimore City Trauma-Informed Care Task Force.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Task Force comprises 37 members, 30 of whom are appointed by the Mayor under Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter and 7 of whom are ex-officio members.

para.heading: Appointed members.
para.text: Of the 30 members appointed by the Mayor:
3 shall be youth representatives from a youth-led advocacy group in Baltimore City;
2 shall be individuals with at least one child enrolled in the Baltimore City Public School System;
1 shall be a licensed clinician with an expertise in trauma and healing;
2 shall be members of the research community with an expertise in trauma and healing;
1 shall be a representative of an organization with an explicit focus on racial equity in its organizational mission statement;
1 shall be an individual between 14 and 25 years of age;
1 shall be a individual licensed to practice in the State of Maryland as a physician with a specialty in pediatrics;
1 shall be a representative of an organization with an explicit focus on lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) advocacy in its organizational mission statement;
1 shall be a naturalized citizen or a resident alien;
1 shall be an individual who has recently exited from the Maryland correctional system;
1 shall be an employee of the Baltimore City Public School System;
3 shall be representatives from community organizations, nonprofit organizations, or youth organizations that have an expertise in trauma and healing;
2 shall be educators within the Baltimore City Public School System;
2 shall be individuals licensed to practice in the State of Maryland as social workers; and
8 shall be recommended by the City Council President as follows:
2 City Councilmembers as follows:
1 Councilmember with experience as an educator within the Baltimore City Public School System, who shall serve as co-chair if appointed; and
1 Councilmember with experience as a parent of a student within the Baltimore City Public School System;
1 youth representative from a youth-led advocacy group in
Baltimore City;
1 representative of an organization with an explicit focus on
racial equity in its organizational mission statement;
1 licensed clinician with an expertise in trauma and healing;
and
3 representatives from community organizations, nonprofit organizations, or youth-led or youth-oriented organizations that have an expertise in trauma and healing.

para.heading: Ex-officio (or designate) members.
para.text: The 7 ex-officio members of the Task Force are:
the Director of the Office;
the Commissioner of the Baltimore City Department of Health or the Commissioner's designee;
the Director of the Department of Planning or the Director's designee;
the Director of the Department of Recreation and Parks or the Director's designee;
the Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee;
the City Council President; and
the Youth Commission Chair.

section.heading: Trauma-Informed Care Task Force – Terms, organization, etc.

para.heading: Terms.
para.text: Appointed members serve for a term of 4 years concurrent with the term of the Mayor's term of office.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: Members serve on the Task Force without compensation.
At the end of a term, an appointed member serves until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves out the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Task Force shall meet on the call of one or both of the Task Force co-chairs as frequently as required to perform its duties, but not less than 6 times a year.
A majority of the members of the Task Force constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business, and an affirmative vote by the majority of a quorum is sufficient for any official action.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As provided in this subsection, the Task Force shall have 2 co-chairs designated.

para.heading: At-large co-chair.
para.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Mayor may designate any member of the Task Force to serve as 1 of the co-chairs.

para.heading: Council member co-chair.
para.text: The City Council President shall designate the City Councilmember serving ex-officio under ྷ 22-17(b)(15)(i)(A) as co-chair of the task force.

section.heading: Trauma-Informed Care Task Force – Staff.
section.text: The Office shall provide adequate staff for the Task Force to carry out its duties.

section.heading: Trauma-Informed Care Task Force – Duties.
section.text: The Task Force shall:

para.text: assist in the identification of all City programs and services that impact children and youth;
assist in the development of a citywide strategy toward an organizational culture shift into a trauma-responsive City government;
establish metrics, in collaboration with the Baltimore City Department of Health, to evaluate and assess the progress of the citywide trauma-informed care initiative;
coordinate and develop with the Baltimore City Department of Health any formal or informal trauma-informed care training;
disseminate information within City government regarding best practices for preventing and mitigating the impact of trauma on and facilitating healing with children, youth, and families;
advise and assist the Mayor and City Council in providing oversight and accountability in implementing the requirements of this part;
perform any other duties as required by the Mayor.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Agency.
para.text: "Agency" means:
the Baltimore City Fire Department;
the Baltimore City Parking Authority;
the Department of Finance;
the Department of Law;
the Department of Housing and Community Development;
the Department of Planning;
the Department of Public Works;
the Department of Recreation and Parks;
the Department of Transportation;
the Environmental Control Board;
the Enoch Pratt Free Library of Baltimore City;
the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice;
the Mayor's Office of Employment Development; and
the Mayor's Office of Homeless Services.

para.heading: Formal training.
para.text: "Formal training" means a didactic course or curriculum in trauma-informed care that is:
developed by the United States Department of Health and Human Services, Maryland Department of Health, or the Baltimore City Department of Health; and
provided by the Baltimore City Department of Health or its designee in collaboration with the Task Force.

para.heading: Task Force members.
para.text: Each Task Force member shall participate in at least 1 formal training each year.
Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, each agency head shall designate 2 agency staff members to:
participate in at least 1 formal training each year;
collaborate with other agency designees in periodic worksessions and other informal trainings as organized by the Baltimore City Department of Health from time to time;
serve as the principal advisors to the agency head and agency staff in trauma-responsiveness and trauma-informed care;

collaborate with the agency's equity coordinator, as designated under ྷ 39-8 {"Agency implementation – Equity Coordinator"} of this article, to ensure that the agency's equity assessment program is trauma-informed and trauma-responsive;
assess the agency for training and technical assistance needs related to trauma-responsiveness and trauma-informed care; and
review and make appropriate recommendations to the agency head to align agency policies and practices with a trauma-intensive approach.
Of the 2 agency staff members designated under paragraph (1) of this subsection:
1 staff member shall be an individual who:
has decision-making authority in developing City policy; or
serves as a principal advisor to the agency head; and
1 staff member shall be an individual who, within the course of the individual's City employment, routinely and directly interacts with community members.
In the event of a vacancy of one or both of the staff members, the agency head shall, within 90 days of the vacancy, designate another staff member to carry out the duties of this subsection.

The Baltimore City Department of Health shall provide any technical advisory support to designated agency staff in order for those individuals to carry out their duties under subsection (c)(1) of this section.
The Department of Human Resources shall ensure compliance with the requirements of this section and report to the Task Force as necessary any difficulties regarding agency implementation.

para.heading: Progress report to Task Force.
para.text: On or before March 31 of each year, each agency head shall submit to the Task Force a progress report detailing its agency's progress and compliance with subsection (c) of this section.

section.heading: Annual report.
section.text: On or before June 30 of each year, utilizing its established evaluation and assessment metrics and its expertise, the Task Force shall submit a report to the Mayor and City Council containing:

para.text: an assessment of the implementation of trauma-informed care within each agency as defined in § 22-21(a)(2) of this subtitle;
an assessment of the trauma-responsiveness of each agency as defined in § 22-21(a)(2) of this subtitle; and
any recommendations regarding improvements to existing laws relating to children, youth, and families in Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As used in this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated unless their context clearly indicates otherwise.

para.heading: City.
para.text: "City" means the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, the body corporate as established by the Charter of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Commission.
para.text: "Commission" means the Mayor's Commission on Disabilities.

para.heading: Other terms.
para.text: Any other term used in this subtitle shall be defined as such terms are defined in the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, as amended, and the federal regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, as amended.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: It is the purpose of this Commission to:

para.text: advise the City on the accessibility of City facilities, programs, and services for citizens with disabilities;
assist the City to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990; and

assist the City in providing information and education programs to City government, businesses, and industries with regard to reasonable accommodations for employment and other issues concerning persons with disabilities.

section.heading: Commission established.
section.text: There is a Mayor's Commission on Disabilities.

para.text: The Commission consists of 23 members:
a Mayor's representative;
a representative of the City Council; and
21 members appointed by the Mayor under Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter as follows:
9 persons with disabilities, not employed in the field of disabilities;
3 family members of persons with disabilities; and
9 representatives of business, industry, community organizations, non-profit organizations, and organizations representing persons with disabilities, at least 3 of whom are persons with disabilities.
Of the members appointed under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection, at least 1 must be appointed from each of the 14 Council Districts.
Each member appointed under paragraph (1)(iii)C of this subsection must work or reside in the City.

para.heading: Associates.
para.text: One representative from each of the following agencies serves as a non-voting associate:
Commission on Aging and Retirement Education.
Health Department.
Department of Recreation and Parks.
Department of Planning.
Department of Housing and Community Development.
Department of Human Resources.
Department of Transportation.
Law Department.
Community Relations Commission.
Baltimore City Public School System.
Office of Employment Development.
Police Department.
Department of Social Services.
Fire Department.
Department of Transportation.
Enoch Pratt Free Library.
Office of Emergency Management.

para.heading: Terms.
para.text: Members serve for a term of 4 years concurrent with the Mayor's term of office.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: Members and associates serve without compensation.
At the end of a term, an appointed member serves until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves out the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Commission shall meet on the call of the Mayor or its Chair as frequently as required to perform its duties, but not less than 6 times a year.
A majority of the members of the Commission constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business, and an affirmative vote by the majority of a quorum is sufficient for any official action.

para.heading: Rules.
para.text: The Commission may adopt rules to govern its meetings and operations.

para.heading: Failure to attend meetings.
para.text: Any member who is absent from more than 25% of the scheduled regular meetings, not counting absences excused by the Chair, during any 6-month period, shall be considered by the Mayor to have resigned and shall be so notified by the Commission.
The Mayor shall designate an appointed member, representing the membership category identified in § 23-4(a)(3)(i), as Chair of the Commission.
The Chair may select other officers.

para.heading: Committees.
para.text: The Chair of the Commission may appoint committees to carry out the functions and duties of the Commission.

para.heading: Invited participants.
para.text: Representatives of state agencies and other organizations that serve the interests of the disabled in Baltimore City may be invited by the Commission to participate in Commission meetings.

section.heading: Duties.
section.text: The Commission shall:

para.text: assist in the development of a transition plan for the City of Baltimore to address community access to facilities, open spaces, and communications, and advise the Mayor on the implementation of the plan by January 26, 1995;
assist in the identification and evaluation of all City programs and services that impact the major life activities of persons with disabilities;
recommend modification of services or new services for persons with disabilities;
research, assemble, analyze and disseminate pertinent data and educational materials relating to activities and programs which will assist in meeting the needs of persons with disabilities;
work to eliminate discrimination of persons with disabilities;

in consultation with the Division of Occupational Medicine and the Community Relations Commission, institute and conduct educational programs, meetings, and conferences designed to promote equal rights and opportunities for persons with disabilities;
cooperate with interested citizens, general community, business, professional, technical, educational, and civic organizations in furthering the interests of persons with disabilities;
work jointly with other jurisdictions on conducting similar activities;
work to remove inequalities due to unmet needs or discrimination on the basis of disability in the areas of housing, recreation, employment, education, community services, and related matters;
cooperate and collaborate with all municipal agencies, including the Division of Occupational Medicine and the Community Relations Commission, to avoid duplication of efforts;

provide information to the residents of the City, the Mayor's Office, the City Council, and various offices of the city, state, and federal government on matters involving the needs of persons with disabilities;
recommend programs or legislation as necessary to promote and insure equal rights and opportunities for all persons with disabilities;
work to assure that information and referral needs are met and that information about City programs is disseminated;
hold a public forum at least yearly to give persons with disabilities an opportunity to voice their concerns;
work to assure the development of an effective delivery system of public, private, and consumer resources to all persons with disabilities;
assist the Director of the Commission with regard to inquiries, complaints, and other problems with City services for persons with disabilities;
assist in the coordination of state and federal programs and services available to the City, business, and industry; and
provide other advice as requested by the Mayor, City Council, and municipal agencies.

para.heading: Appointment of Director.
para.text: In consultation with the Commission, the Mayor shall appoint a Director of the Commission in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.

para.heading: Duties.
para.text: The Director shall perform duties as required by the Mayor to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

para.heading: Staff.
para.text: Staff may be employed in accordance with the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Budget.
para.text: The Director may expend funds authorized in the Ordinance of Estimates or any supplemental appropriations.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: The Commission shall submit an annual report to the Mayor and City Council within 2 months of the end of the fiscal year.

para.heading: Other reports.
para.text: The Commission shall submit reports on specific subjects at the request of the Mayor, City Council, or municipal agencies.

para.heading: Homeless.
para.text: A person shall be considered homeless if:
the person has no present possessory interest in a living accommodation and lacks the means necessary to obtain such interest; or
the person has a possessory interest in a living accommodation but:
the person is unable to secure entry to that accommodation; or
occupation of the accommodation would likely lead to violence from another occupant.

para.heading: Adequate shelter.
para.text: Adequate shelter is that which to a reasonable degree maintains, protects, and supports human health, is accessible, safe, and sanitary, and has an atmosphere of reasonable dignity.

section.heading: Declaration of policy.
section.text: In the interest of preventing human suffering and reducing the costs of providing medical care and police protection, and in recognition of the need of all persons to adequate overnight shelter, it is the public policy of the City of Baltimore to assist the private sector in providing adequate overnight shelter and services for all homeless persons in Baltimore requesting such shelter and willing to abide by reasonable regulations governing the use of shelter facilities.

section.heading: Annual assessments.
section.text: On or before October 31 of each year, the Office of Homeless Services shall publish an assessment of:

para.text: the number of homeless persons in the City who desire overnight shelter; and
current shelter availability and adequacy.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Confiscated Assets for Neighborhoods Grant Program in the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice.

para.heading: Purpose.
para.text: The purpose of the Grant Program is to fund community-based safety initiatives.

para.heading: Source of funding.
para.text: Funding for the Grants Program shall derive from a portion of all money confiscated by the Police Department and forfeited to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, as appropriated in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Allocation among police districts.
para.text: Each year, this funding shall be allocated among the various police districts, prorated generally according to the percentage that money confiscated from a district in the preceding year bears to all money confiscated Citywide in that year.

para.heading: Eligible applicants.
para.text: Any established neighborhood association or other community-based organization active within a police district may apply for a grant from the funds allocated to that district.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The application shall contain the information and be in the form that the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice requires.

para.heading: Referral to council.
para.text: Each application for available grant money in a police district shall be referred for review and recommendation to that district's community relations council.

para.heading: Recommendation by council.
para.text: The community relations council shall submit its recommendations to the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice.

section.heading: Decisions by Office of Criminal Justice.

para.heading: Office to make all decisions.
para.text: The Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice shall make all decisions approving or disapproving an application and, making a grant, may impose any limitations or conditions that it considers necessary or appropriate.

para.heading: Office's decisions final.
para.text: All decisions of the Office under this subtitle are final and non-appealable.

para.heading: Office to adopt.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Mayor's Office of Criminal Justice shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle and the grant program established under it.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: Among other things, these rules and regulations may further define:
words or phrases used in this subtitle;
qualifications for grant applicants;
procedures for awarding grants; and
procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds.
