container.heading: Mayor's Task Force on Community Collaboration to Overcome Violence

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As used in this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated unless their context clearly indicates otherwise.

para.heading: City.
para.text: "City" means the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, the body corporate as established by the Charter of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Task Force.
para.text: "Task Force" means the Mayor's Task Force on Community Collaboration to Overcome Violence.

para.heading: Violence.
para.text: "Violence" means:
the harmful use of physical or emotional force by an individual or group against another; also
the creation and/or maintenance of conditions that degrade individuals, families, groups, or communities.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: It is the purpose of this subtitle to:

para.text: review and understand the issue of individual, family, community, criminal, and societal violence in Baltimore City;
examine the causes of violence;
consider methods to prevent the different types of violence;
establish systems to deliver existing social, governmental, and economic resources to relieve conditions that may lead to violence;
provide information, education, and assistance to communities, businesses, and government about programs that prevent violence; and
generally address the need to develop the well being of the citizens of Baltimore City in order to eliminate violence as a means of conflict resolution.

section.heading: Task Force created.
section.text: There is a Mayor's Task Force on Community Collaboration to Overcome Violence.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Task Force shall consist of 27 members.

para.heading: Public members.
para.text: 16 members shall be appointed by the Mayor pursuant to Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter:
3 members shall be non-profit or public community social workers;
1 member shall be a representative of a community organization;
1 member shall be a representative of the business community;
1 member shall be a senior citizen;
1 member shall be a community psychiatric nurse, nurse practitioner, or a physician;
1 member shall be a public assistance client;
1 member shall be a victim of violence;
1 member shall be a family member of a victim of violent crime;
1 member shall be an ex-offender;
1 member shall be a community public school teacher;
1 representative from the Interdenominational Ministerial Alliance; and
3 other representatives from the Baltimore City religious community.

para.heading: Agency representatives.
para.text: Representatives from the following City agencies shall serve as members of the Task Force who shall serve ex officio:
a Mayor's representative;
a representative of the City Council;
Police Department –– a community relations officer;
Health Commissioner or representative designated by the Commissioner;
Commission on Aging and Retirement Education;
Baltimore Development Corporation;
Office of Employment Development;
Department of Planning;
Department of Housing and Community Development;
Department of Human Resources;
Law Department;
Community Relations Commission;
Department of Education;
a representative from the Mayor's Interagency Task Force on Youth Violence Prevention; and
a representative from the Baltimore City Department of Social Services.

para.heading: City Council Districts.
para.text: Of the members appointed under subsection (b), 1 shall be appointed from each of the 6 Councilmanic districts.

para.heading: Residency.
para.text: Members appointed by the Mayor shall be residents of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Terms.
para.text: Members shall serve for a 4-year term concurrent with the Mayor's term of office.

para.heading: Compensation.
para.text: Members shall serve without compensation.
At the end of a term an appointed member serves until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves out the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Task Force shall meet on the call of the Mayor or Chair as frequently as required to perform its duties, but not less than 6 times each year.
A majority of the members of the Task Force shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and an affirmative vote by the majority of a quorum shall be sufficient for any official action.

para.heading: Rules.
para.text: The Task Force may adopt rules to govern its meetings and operations, which shall be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference.

para.heading: Failure to attend meetings.
para.text: Any member who is absent from more than 25% of the scheduled regular meetings, not counting absences excused by the chair, during any 6-month period, shall be considered by the Mayor to have resigned.

para.heading: Officers.
para.text: The Mayor shall designate an appointed member as Chair of the Task Force. The Task Force may select other officers.

para.heading: Committees.
para.text: The Chair of the Task Force may appoint committees to carry out the functions and duties of the Task Force.

para.heading: Participation by others.
para.text: Representatives of State and federal agencies and other organizations that serve the interests of the disabled in Baltimore City shall be invited by the Task Force to participate in its meetings

section.heading: Duties.
section.text: The Task Force shall:

para.text: review and understand the issue of individual, family, community, criminal, and societal violence in Baltimore City;
examine the causes of violence;
consider methods to prevent the different types of violence;
recommend systems to deliver existing social, governmental, and economic resources to relieve conditions that may lead to violence;
provide information, education, and assistance to communities, businesses, government, and industries about programs that prevent violence;
assist in the identification, establishment, and evaluation of all City programs and services that affect violence prevention;
recommend modification of services or new services for the prevention of situations that could lead to violence;
cooperate with interested citizens, general community, business, professional, technical, educational, and civic organizations in furthering the violence prevention programs;
coordinate with other jurisdictions on sharing violence prevention strategies and information;

cooperate and collaborate with all municipal agencies, including the Division of Occupational Safety in the Department of Finance and the Community Relations Commission, to avoid duplication of efforts;

compile and provide information to the residents, community organizations, and businesses of the City, the Mayor's Office, the City Council, and various offices of the City, State, and federal government on matters involving methods and strategies for recognizing and preventing violence;
recommend to the Mayor, City, State, and federal programs or legislation to promote violence prevention as a means of conflict resolution;
work to assure that information and referral needs are met and that information about City programs is disseminated;

hold a public forum at least yearly to give communities an opportunity to voice their concerns regarding violence and the effectiveness of violence prevention programs and to make recommendations to the Task Force;
assist in the coordination of State and federal programs and services available to the City, business, and industry to prevent violence;
coordinate economic development opportunities that may be available for those citizens and communities in need of violence prevention;
develop an information program for the media to disseminate practices, methods, and procedures to be followed to avoid violence; and
generally assist in the development of the well being of the citizens of Baltimore City in order to eliminate violence as a means of conflict resolution.

para.heading: Staff.
para.text: Staff may be employed in accordance with the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Funds.
para.text: The Task Force may expend funds authorized in the Ordinance of Estimates or any supplemental appropriations.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: The Task Force shall submit an annual report to the Mayor and City Council within 2 months of the end of the fiscal year.

para.heading: Other reports.
para.text: The Task Force shall submit reports on specific subjects regarding violence at the request of the Mayor, City Council, or municipal agencies.

para.heading: Filing.
para.text: A copy of all reports shall be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference.

container.heading: Good Samaritan: Citizen Injured While Aiding Police

section.heading: Policy.
section.text: It is declared to be the policy of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, within the limits hereinafter prescribed, to compensate certain private citizens or, in case of death, certain survivors, where injury, property damage, or death result from assisting in law enforcement activities.

section.heading: Board of Estimates may make awards.

para.heading: When authorized.
para.text: The Board of Estimates is hereby authorized and empowered in its discretion to make an award for the death of or injury to any private citizen which has been directly caused:

while such person is assisting or coming to the aid of a member of the Police Department of Baltimore City while making an arrest or otherwise engaged in enforcing the laws, ordinances, or regulations of the State of Maryland or the City of Baltimore; or
while such private citizen:
is attempting to prevent the commission of a crime; or
is in fresh pursuit of one who has committed a crime.

para.heading: Determinations.
para.text: In deciding on the making of an award in the circumstances above outlined, the Board of Estimates shall have the sole discretion to determine:
the amount of the award;
to whom it shall be payable in the event that the said citizen suffer death as a result of his intervention; and
in the event that such private citizen is not acting in aid of a police officer:
whether the crime sought to be prevented was actually occurring and was of such nature as to warrant the intervention of a private citizen; or
whether a crime had occurred and was of such a nature as to warrant pursuit by a private citizen.

para.heading: Source of funds.
para.text: The award herein authorized may be paid from the Contingent Fund of the Board.

para.heading: "Private citizen" defined.
para.text: The term "private citizen" as used herein shall not include a paid guard or other security officer while engaged in the protection of property or persons he is employed to guard.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Such sum as may be awarded:
shall be granted by the Board of Estimates as a matter of grace and not as a matter of right; and
shall be such compensation as the Board in its judgment deems to be right and proper under the circumstances, subject to the following limitations.
In the case of personal injury, the award shall be limited:
to the injured person's medical, hospital, and other such expenses; and
to his loss of net earning or take-home pay, if any, during the time he is unable to work as a direct result of such injuries.
If such person received workmen's compensation or other insurance payments as a result of such injuries, the award shall be reduced by the amount of such payments.
If such person is unemployed and not receiving unemployment insurance at the time of such injuries, the Board in its discretion may award him a sum not exceeding $1,000.

para.heading: Property damage.
para.text: In the case of property damage, the award shall be limited to the actual value of the property damaged.
In the case of the death of such person, the award shall be to:
the surviving spouse;
dependent child or children under the age of 18;
the person responsible for payment of funeral expenses of the deceased citizen;
other dependents or relatives of such deceased citizen to whom he at the time of death was contributing at least 50% financial support; or
any combination of the above in the discretion of the Board.

Such award may be a lump sum payment in the discretion of the Board or in its discretion may be made in periodic payments not exceeding the amount of such person's net or take-home wages, salary, or other earned income at the time of such occurrence, or the amount of the special death benefits payable upon the death of a beginning or 1st -year patrolman of the Baltimore City Police Department, as provided, and in the manner provided in Article 22, § 34(i) of the City Code, whichever is less.
The Board shall retain continuing jurisdiction over each such case and may change the amount of the periodic payments or stop them altogether at any time, in its best judgment.
Petitions for such award may be made informally to the Board by a written statement of the circumstances surrounding the incident giving rise to the claim.
Such petition for compensation shall be filed with the Board within 1 year of the date of the personal injury, property damage, or death.

para.heading: Review and report by Law Department.
para.text: Upon receiving a claim filed under the provisions of this section, the Board shall refer such claim to the Law Department for full investigation and prompt report to the Board.

para.heading: Hearing discretionary with Board.
para.text: In the discretion of the Board, a hearing may or may not be held and a payment may be made within the above limits without a hearing.

para.heading: Board's decision final.
para.text: Such payment being a matter of grace and not of right, no appeal shall lie from and no further proceedings shall be had after the decision of the Board in a given case.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Board of Estimates may adopt and from time to time change reasonable rules and regulations for the administration of this section which are not in conflict with the intent and specific wording hereof.

section.heading: Assignment and release.
section.text: Before any payment is made under this subtitle, the claimant:

para.text: shall execute and deliver to the City an instrument, in such form as may be approved by the City Solicitor, assigning to the City all rights and claims which he may have against third persons as a result of the occurrence for which the claim is being made, up to the amount of the City's award to such claimant; and
shall fully release the City from all claims and liabilities of any kind whatsoever arising out of such occurrence, on a form approved by the City Solicitor.

section.heading: Authorization reduced by like State award.
section.text: In the event that the State enacts legislation on the same general subject covered by this subtitle, the amounts authorized hereunder shall be reduced by the amount of any benefit paid or payable under such State law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Authority.
para.text: "Authority" means the Child First Authority.

para.heading: Board.
para.text: "Board" means the Board of Directors of the Authority.

para.heading: Executive Director.
para.text: "Executive Director" means the Executive Director of the Authority.

para.heading: Authority established.
para.text: There is a Child First Authority.

para.heading: Purpose.
para.text: The purpose of the Authority is to enhance the development of children in Baltimore City by providing recreational, cultural, academic, and other enrichment programs for children in approximately 40 schools in the City during an extended school day.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The powers of the Authority shall be broadly interpreted to allow the Authority to achieve the purposes of Article II, § (64) of the City Charter and this subtitle.

para.heading: Enumeration.
para.text: In addition to any other powers specified in this subtitle, the Authority may:
acquire, lease, or hold both real and personal property for the purposes of the Authority;
engage the services of an Executive Director, which may be an individual or an entity, to administer the programs and undertakings of the Authority;
sue and be sued;
accept grants and other revenue from individuals and public or private foundations, agencies, organizations, and entities necessary or beneficial to carry out the purposes of the Authority;
borrow funds for purposes consistent with the public purposes of the Authority;
incur limited-obligation debt that shall be an obligation solely of the Authority;
create and enter into partnerships and contracts with the Baltimore City Public Schools to provide services and benefits in exchange for payments in cash or in kind or without charge;

contract for and purchase goods and services without being subject to approval by the Board of Estimates, but subject to the provisions of Article 5 of the City Code governing the prevailing wage and governing City policy on encouraging and achieving goals for Minority and Women's Business Enterprises' participation in the contracting activities of the Authority;
implement the programs and goals of the Authority directly through employees, or through 1 or more contracts, which contracts may be with independent contractors or contractual employees;
appoint, hire, or engage such auditors, accountants, attorneys, assistants, aides, employees, and advisors as it deems necessary and consistent with this subtitle; and
do all other things necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes and powers of the Authority.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: To the extent not specifically made subject to laws and procedures that would otherwise apply to any unit of the City government, the Authority is exempt from those laws and procedures.

para.heading: City funding.
para.text: However, if the Authority is given direct City funding, the receipt and expenditure of those funds are subject to the powers and authority of the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Authority may not:

be or constitute or be deemed an agency of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore or the State of Maryland, and its officers and employees may not act as agents or employees of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore or the State of Maryland;
exercise any power specifically withheld by the terms of the Charter or this subtitle;
exercise any police powers other than those expressly authorized by state or local law;
pledge the full faith and credit of the City or otherwise obligate the City to any debt, obligation, or contract;
have any taxing authority; or
exercise the power of eminent domain.

para.heading: Indemnification of Mayor and City Council.
para.text: The Authority shall indemnify and hold harmless the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore and its officers, agents, and employees against all acts, conditions, damages, suits, claims, and liabilities arising out of or in connection with any activities of the Authority or of its board, executive director, officers, agents, or employees.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Authority shall be governed and administered by its Board of Directors.

para.heading: Appointment; Terms.
para.text: The Board members shall be appointed and serve the terms prescribed by the Authority's Bylaws.

para.heading: Bylaws.
para.text: The Board shall adopt, and may amend from time to time, Bylaws, not inconsistent with the Charter or this subtitle, for the administration of the Authority.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Except as may be restricted by the Charter or this subtitle, the Board may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Of Authority.
para.text: The Bylaws shall provide for officers of the Authority, including a president, vice-president, treasurer, secretary, and any other officers deemed necessary or appropriate, and shall specify their qualifications, terms, and duties.

para.heading: Of Board.
para.text: The Board shall select from among its members individuals to serve as officers of the Board and may delegate to those officers the responsibilities the Board deems appropriate.

para.heading: Exercise of Authority's powers.
para.text: All powers of the Authority shall be exercised by the Board, unless delegated by the Board to 1 or more of the officers or to the Executive Director.
The Executive Director may exercise the powers granted to the Authority under this subtitle.
However, the Board shall retain final discretion and power with regard to all substantive agreements, contracts, and other arrangements binding on the Authority.

para.heading: Duties.
para.text: The Executive Director shall:
be responsible for the day-to-day operations of the Authority and its employees and contractors;
prepare the financial plan for review and approval by the Board;
implement the approved financial plan and arrange for the collection and disbursement of all charges, fees, and revenues of the Authority;
establish procedures and processes necessary to perform the functions called for under the financial plan and the budget;
hire and retain the employees, agents, and contractors needed to perform the functions of the Executive Director, subject to the requirements of § 28-3(b)(8) of this subtitle;
be the agent of the Authority; and
have such further rights, powers, and authority as granted by the Board.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: Any limitations on the powers and authority of the Board shall apply as well to the Executive Director in performing the functions charged to the Executive Director by this subtitle or by the Board.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On or before January 31 of each odd-numbered year, the Baltimore City Department of Health shall present to the City Council a comprehensive violence prevention strategy plan for the subsequent 2 years.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Baltimore City Department of Health shall coordinate and develop the plan in direct consultation with:
the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development;
the Baltimore City Department of Public Works;
the Baltimore City Department of Recreation and Parks;
the Baltimore City Department of Social Services;
the Baltimore City Department of Transportation;
the Baltimore City Fire Department;
the Baltimore City Police Department;
the Baltimore City Public School System;
the Baltimore City State's Attorney's Office;
the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention;
the Housing Authority of Baltimore City;
the Mayor's Office of Children and Family Success;
the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management;
the Mayor's Office of Homeless Services; and
the State Department of Juvenile Services.

para.heading: Qualification.
para.text: Only the entities listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection that are municipal agencies as defined in City Charter Article I, ྷ 2(j) {"Definitions: Municipal agency"} are required to assist and participate with the Baltimore City Department of Health in this endeavor.
The plan required by this section shall focus on the social determinative outcomes of health, as described by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, by:
analyzing available City data regarding criminal justice, health, education, public works, transportation, housing, lead paint, drug overdoses, and any other relevant dataset;
outlining public health and safety strategies, including setting goals for prevention, intervention, enforcement, rehabilitation, and re-entry;
setting forth holistic, non-policing efforts aimed at violence prevention;

establishing goals, priorities, and standards for the prevention of violence, the reduction of harm, the remediation of trauma, and the overall improvement of health disparities within Baltimore City; and

utilizing any other data, metric, or methodology that the Department of Health believes to be within the best practices for the prevention of violence, the reduction of harm, the remediation of trauma, and the overall improvement of health disparities within Baltimore City.

After the initial plan, each subsequent plan under this section must include an analysis, utilizing qualitative and quantitative data, of the specific strategies outlined in the previous plan in order to assess the effectiveness of those strategies.
Publication of plan and comment.
The plan required by this section shall be posted prominently for public comment on the City's website for no less than 30 days prior to its submission to the City Council.
After the public comment period has concluded and prior to submission to the City Council, the Baltimore City Department of Health may amend or revise its plan to:
reflect the public comments received; or
include updated data.
Any comments received shall be included with the plan on its submission to the City Council.

para.heading: Interim progress reports.
para.text: No later than January 31 of each even-numbered year, the Baltimore City Department of Health shall submit to the Mayor and City Council an interim progress report detailing the progress of the plan submitted in the previous year, including:
an analysis, assessment, and, if necessary, re-evaluation of any relevant data, strategies, and priorities from the previous year; and

any public education or engagement measures taken or to be taken based on that data to assist in the prevention of violence, the reduction of harm, the remediation of trauma, and the overall improvement of health disparities within Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Cadet.
para.text: "Cadet" means a participant in the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program who:
has been hired into a specialized training program aimed at introducing young adults to public safety careers; and
is at least 18 but no more than 21 years old.

para.heading: Department.
para.text: "Department" means the Baltimore City Fire Department.

para.heading: Explorer.
para.text: "Explorer" means a participant in the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program who is:
a Baltimore City resident;
enrolled in a public, public charter, private, or parochial school within Baltimore City; and
at least 11 but no more than 18 years old.

para.heading: Public safety agency.
para.text: "Public safety agency" means the following:
Baltimore City Fire Department;
Baltimore City Police Department;
Baltimore City Office of Emergency Management;
Baltimore City Sheriff's Office; and
Baltimore City School Police.

para.heading: Public Safety Apprenticeship Program; Program.
para.text: "Public Safety Apprenticeship Program" or "Program" means a program for recruiting, mentoring, training, and hiring a new generation of Baltimore City youth and young adults to prepare them for careers in law enforcement, fire suppression, emergency medical services, and emergency management.

para.heading: Public Safety Cadet Post; Cadet Post.
para.text: "Public Safety Cadet Post" or "Cadet Post" means the branch of the Program that engages participants who are at least 18 but no more than 21 years old.

para.heading: Public Safety Explorer Post; Explorer Post.
para.text: "Public Safety Explorer Post" or "Explorer Post" means the branch of the Program that engages participants who are at least 11 but no more than 18 years old.

para.heading: Public safety internship.
para.text: "Public safety internship" means an 8 to 10 week paid summer internship in a Baltimore City public safety agency for participants in the Program who are at least 14 but no more than 18 years old.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Public Safety Apprenticeship Program in Baltimore City, consisting of:
the Public Safety Explorers Post; and
the Public Safety Cadet Post.

para.heading: Staffing.
para.text: The Program shall be staffed with a reasonable number of uniformed and non-uniformed personnel who are full-time members of a public safety agency.
By January 1, 2023, each participating public safety agency shall develop and implement their own local Public Safety Explorers Post.
The goals and objectives of the Explorers Post are to:
expose youth in Baltimore City to public safety careers;
serve as a local recruitment tool for future men and women in public safety professions;
build better community relations efforts in Baltimore City between public safety agencies, youth, and the community;
utilize active personnel within each of Baltimore City's public safety agencies to serve as recruiters, mentors, and trainers; and
develop programming that builds character, develops leadership skills, and fosters an appreciation for community service and good citizenship.
In order to be eligible to participate in the Explorers Post, an individual shall:
have approval from the individual's parent or guardian;
be at least 11 but no more than 18 years old;
be a Baltimore City resident;
be enrolled in a Baltimore City-based public, public charter, private, or parochial
school; and
be able to safely perform the duties of an explorer without posing a threat to the health and safety of themselves or others.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The public safety internship will provide youth who are current participants in the Program with the opportunity to take part in an 8 to 10 week paid summer internship with a public safety agency.

para.heading: Eligibility.
para.text: In order to be eligible for a public safety internship under the Program, an individual shall:
be at least 14 but no more than 18 years old;
have attended a reasonable number of Explorer Post Activities as determined by the host agency within the fiscal year immediately preceding the application period;
be enrolled in a Baltimore City-based public, public charter, private, or parochial
school;
at the time of entry into the Program, have and maintain a minimum of a "C" average
in school;
be able to safely perform the duties of an explorer without posing a threat to the health and safety of themselves or others.
complete all documentation required by the Department; and
participate in a formal interview process with representatives from public safety
agencies.

para.heading: Curriculum.
para.text: Each participating public safety agency shall develop and implement their own specialized curriculum of modules that expose public safety internship participants to the various uniformed and non-uniformed career paths with the public safety agency.
The Public Safety Cadet Post shall provide eligible individuals who are participants in the Program with the opportunity to:
be hired by a public safety agency in the career track of the participant's choice; and
receive on-the-job training and skills development for a period of not more than 3 years.
In order to be eligible to participate in the Public Safety Cadet Post, an individual shall:
be at least 18 years old but no more than 21 years old; and
meet all of the hiring requirements in accordance with:
the Baltimore City Administrative Manual; and
the rules and regulations governing the public safety agency chosen by the cadet.

Beginning in fiscal year 2023, the Cadet Post shall use a phased-in approach to hire a minimum number of young adults to serve in the law enforcement career track or the fire and emergency medical services career track in the following sequence:
in fiscal year 2023:
10 Emergency Medical Technician ("EMT")/firefighter cadets; and
10 police cadets;
in fiscal year 2024:
15 EMT/firefighter cadets; and
15 police cadets
in fiscal year 2025:
20 EMT/firefighter cadets; and
20 police cadets;
in fiscal year 2026:
25 EMT/firefighter cadets; and
25 police cadets; and
beginning in fiscal year 2027, if funding is available, each agency shall continue to hire a minimum of 25 cadets in each career track.
Fire Department cadet duties shall include:
completion of all Baltimore City Fire Academy training modules and certifications;
an academy and field operations training rotation lasting 18 months; and
all administrative functions that fall into this classification of work as prescribed by
the public safety agency.
Law enforcement cadet duties shall include:
maintaining and filing records;
operating office computers and machines;
answering telephones;
entering and indexing official documents;
preparing routine reports;
preparing and tabulating facts and figures for statistical purposes; and
all other administrative functions that do not require law enforcement authority.

para.heading: Public Safety Apprenticeship Program.
para.text: Program funding shall be subject to an appropriation of funds in accordance with the City Charter.

para.heading: Public safety internship.
para.text: An appropriate allocation of funds may be provided for miscellaneous costs associated with the public safety internship, including transportation fees for participants.

para.heading: Public safety internship compensation.
para.text: Subject to the availability of funds, on or before July 1, 2023, individuals hired to participate in the 8 to 10 week public safety internship shall be paid an amount determined by the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Public Safety Cadet Post compensation.
para.text: Subject to the availability of funds, individuals selected to participate in the Cadet Post shall receive a benefits and compensation package as determined by the Board of Estimates.
On or before June 30 of each year, the Department shall report to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore the following information regarding the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program:
the number and location of recruitment and outreach events that the Program hosted and participated in;
the number of active youth and young adults who participated in at least 60% of the activities hosted by the Explorers Post broken down by sex, age, race, and ethnicity;
the curriculum, modules, and other learning materials that were used for programming to build character, develop leadership, and develop an appreciation for community service and good citizenship;
the number of youth and young adults selected to participate in the public safety internship broken down by sex, age, race, and ethnicity; and
the number of youth and young adults hired into the Public Safety Cadet Post broken down by sex, age, race, and ethnicity.
The information required under paragraph (1) of this subsection:
may not include participants' names; and
shall be disaggregated by race and gender.

para.heading: Other reporting requirements.
para.text: On or before June 30 of each year, the Department shall report the to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore the following information from the previous fiscal year:
the total amount of funds that were appropriated to the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program;
the remaining balance of unused funds that were appropriated to the Public Safety Explorers Post;
the administrative, operational, and programming costs associated with the public safety internship;
the administrative, personnel, and training costs associated with the Public Safety Cadet Post; and
the personnel cost to staff the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program with uniformed personnel.

para.heading: Publication of reports.
para.text: On or before June 30 of each year, the Baltimore City Fire Department shall publish copies of the reports described in this section on the Department's website.

container.heading: Medical Treatment For Service-Connected Disabilities of Retired Policemen and Firemen

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Board of Estimates is hereby authorized and empowered in its discretion, upon proper application by retired policemen and firemen of the City of Baltimore, in cases where such retirement has been occasioned by disabilities sustained in the line of duty, to provide for continuing medical treatment of such retirees.

para.heading: Treatment or payment options.
para.text: Such treatment may be provided at such place or places as the Board may authorize; or in lieu thereof the Board may make a payment to such retiree, payable during disability or in a lump sum, in its discretion; or the Board may provide both medical treatment and a sum of money if the circumstances of a particular case require it.

para.heading: Board may delegate to agency.
para.text: After having passed upon a case in first instance, the Board may delegate to the retiree's former department or to a suitable department or agency of the City the implementation of its award and the question of whether or not such award is to be permanent or temporary in nature.

para.heading: Board retains jurisdiction.
para.text: In each case, however:
the Board retains jurisdiction and responsibility for the execution of this subtitle in accordance with its declared intent; and
any decision by a subordinate official or agency may be informally appealed or brought before the Board for review.

para.heading: Board may adopt.
para.text: The Board is authorized and empowered to promulgate and adopt suitable rules and regulations for the implementation of this section.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: Such rules shall provide generally for:
the determination of what medical treatment is required in a particular case;
the approximate amount to be allowed;
where such retirees should be treated, if at all, and by whom, using City facilities and personnel where practicable; and
whether a sum of money should be payable in lieu of medical services or in addition thereto.

para.heading: Informal petition.
para.text: Upon retirement of a City policeman or fireman because of injuries sustained in line of duty and in cases where such disability is continuing, he may informally petition the Board for the services or payments herein provided. Such petition may be by a letter or other document referring the Board to his departmental case.

para.heading: Referral for investigation and report.
para.text: Upon receipt of such petition, the Board may:
refer such matter back to the department from which the claimant has been retired for full investigation and prompt report to the Board; or
refer such claim to any other agency of the City, including the Law Department for investigation by its Central Bureau of Investigation.

Upon receipt of such report, the Board shall act in disposing of the claim before it. In doing so it may act solely upon the record before it or it may call the claimant and other witnesses to aid in its determination of such matter.

Where there is a dispute as to whether a retiree's medical condition is service-connected and should be compensated under this section, a decision of the Board after full investigation shall be deemed final and conclusive.

section.heading: Other payments as offset.
section.text: Any other payments now or hereafter financed wholly or in part from public funds, including but not limited to workmen's compensation, intended to meet the same expense or provide the same service with respect to the same medical condition, shall serve as an offset against the payments herein provided.

para.heading: Board to decide award.
para.text: Such sum as may be provided herein or such services as may be furnished shall be such as the Board in its judgment determines to be right and proper under the circumstances.

para.heading: Board's decision final.
para.text: And the decision of the Board in any particular case, or in any stage of any such case, shall be final and conclusive and not subject to appeal.

para.heading: Initial year.
para.text: Funding of this compensation provision during the City Fiscal Year 1970-71 shall be from the respective budget of the Police and Fire Departments.

para.heading: Subsequent years.
para.text: After such initial year, funds to sustain awards shall be available as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

container.heading: Occupational Medical Service and Occupational Safety

section.heading: Occupational Medical Service – established.
section.text: There is a City of Baltimore Occupational Medical Service in the Department of Finance, Office of Risk Management.

section.heading: Occupational Medical Service – duties.
section.text: The Occupational Medical Service shall:

para.text: establish medical procedures and standards at all City medical facilities for employees and assure conformity with such procedures and standards;
examine and treat patients at a central medical services clinic;
monitor the quality of medical treatments for all City employees;
investigate and evaluate all City employee safety and health hazards, including but not limited to toxic materials, and establish programs to eliminate and reduce hazards;
evaluate medical cases of patients, including employees with disability claims, at all City medical facilities and recommend upon their disposition;

cooperate with and assist the Law Department and other City agencies involved in Workers' Compensation Commission claims and disability retirement claims and matters relative thereto, improving all types of claims management and loss control;
develop and maintain programs for controlling sick leave, substance abuse, and disability of all City employees and for monitoring and reducing absenteeism;
cooperate with public health agencies in improving the quality of occupational medicine;
maintain a system of uniform medical records; and
develop and maintain programs to enhance the professional education of all employees involved in occupational medicine.

section.heading: Division of Occupational Safety — established.
section.text: There is a Division of Occupational Safety in the Department of Finance, Office of Risk Management.

section.heading: Division of Occupational Safety — duties.
section.text: The Division of Occupational Safety shall:

para.text: develop and administer City-wide safety programs for the prevention of accidents, illnesses, and injuries;
develop and monitor safety programs in City departments, boards, commissions, and agencies and work with agency safety personnel to assure the effectiveness of said programs;
advise the Mayor, the Director, and City agencies in all aspects of employee safety and the safety of the public related to City activities;

investigate and report upon occupational injuries and illnesses and maintain a related record system designed to reduce occupational hazards and ensure responsibility and compliance by all City departments, boards, commissions, and agencies;
assure the adherence of City agencies to City safety policies;
keep abreast of all laws and regulations affecting employee safety and advise City management thereon;
maintain relationships with appropriate federal and state regulatory agencies affecting safety and with relevant professional organizations; and
develop and maintain programs to enhance the professional education of all employees involved in safety activities.

section.heading: Commission established.
section.text: There is a Social Services Commission, as established in Article VII, § 58 of the City Charter.

section.heading: Composition.
section.text: The Commission comprises the following 13 members:

para.text: the Mayor or the Mayor's designee;
the Commissioner of Health or the Commissioner's designee;
the City Council President or the President's designee; and
10 members appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the City Council in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The term of an appointed member expires at the end of the Mayor's term of office.

para.heading: Hold over.
para.text: At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

para.heading: Designation.
para.text: The Mayor shall designate one of the appointed members to serve as President of the Commission.

para.heading: Tenure.
para.text: The member so designated serves as President at the pleasure of the Mayor.

section.heading: Powers and duties.
section.text: The Commission has the powers and duties prescribed by State and City law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, the following definitions apply:

para.heading: Development Commission.
para.text: "The Development Commission" is that which is set forth in Article VII, §§111 through 113 of the City Charter.

para.heading: Component of nuclear weapon.
para.text: "Component of a nuclear weapon" is any device, radioactive or non-radioactive, specifically designed to be installed in and to contribute to the operation of a nuclear weapon.

para.heading: Direct activities of federal government.
para.text: "Direct activities of the federal government" means actions of the federal government or any agency thereof created by statute, but does not include actions of independent contractors.

"Nuclear weapon" is any device, the purpose of which is use as a weapon, a weapon prototype, or a weapon test device, the intended detonation of which results from the energy released by fission and/or fusion reactions involving atomic nuclei.

"Nuclear weapon" includes the weapon's guidance and propulsion system and triggering mechanism, i.e., the means of transporting, guiding, propelling, triggering, or detonating the weapon, provided that such means is destroyed or rendered useless in the normal transporting, guiding, propelling, triggering, or detonation of the weapon.

para.heading: Radioactive materials.
para.text: "Radioactive materials" are any radioactive materials, or their radioactive by-products, which are generated, refined, or made radioactive by any government agency or pursuant to federal or state government contract or license, and including that which the federal government classified as low-level radioactive waste as of January 1, 1989, but which may be classified as below regulatory concern after that date.

section.heading: Exclusions.
section.text: Nothing in this Part shall be construed to prohibit:

para.text: any activity not specifically described in this Part;
basic research and/or any writing or speech devoted to public commentary or debate or other speech protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution;
the use, storage, or treatment and disposal of radioactive materials used in basic academic research, medical research, or the diagnosis and treatment of patients;
consumer uses of radioactive material for smoke detectors, light emitting watches or clocks, industrial radiography and tracer processes, and other similar incidental applications;
direct activities of the federal government or its employees;
the transportation of radioactive materials to and through the Port of Baltimore; and
research, development, and manufacturing associated with biotechnology.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No person shall knowingly within the City of Baltimore design, produce, deploy, launch, maintain, or store nuclear weapons or components of nuclear weapons.

para.heading: Effective date of prohibition.
para.text: In the case of persons with existing contractual agreements for any of the aforementioned activities, this prohibition shall take effect 3 years after the adoption and publication of this Part; otherwise, this Part takes effect upon enactment.

para.heading: New work prohibited.
para.text: No person who is not, as of the effective date of this Part, engaged in the design, production, deployment, launching, maintenance or storage of nuclear weapons or components of nuclear weapons, shall, within the City of Baltimore, commence any such activities after the effective date of this Part.

section.heading: Redirection of resources towards human needs.

para.text: The Development Commission shall determine if any businesses are affected by this Part.
The Development Commission shall then, if necessary:
solicit testimony from the public;
prepare a plan for the conversion to other uses of resources and physical plants affected by this Part; and
develop within this plan, a list of suggested alternative sources of employment for persons currently employed in the nuclear weapons industry.
The conversion plan shall be completed within 3 years of the adoption of this Part.
The Commission shall issue an interim report on its progress within 18 months following the Commission's first meeting.
This interim report shall be presented to the City Council, and copies shall be made available to the news media for public dissemination.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The City shall post and maintain appropriate signs at recognized entrances to the City and in City Hall, proclaiming Baltimore City's status as a nuclear-free zone.

para.heading: Standards.
para.text: When posted on City streets or on state or federally supported roads entering Baltimore City, such signs shall conform with the standards set forth in § 28-44 of the Federal Highway Administration's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways.

section.heading: Civil enforcement.
section.text: Any taxpayer domiciled in the City of Baltimore, any person aggrieved by a violation of this Part, or the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, is authorized to institute an action in the appropriate court of law having jurisdiction, seeking declaratory, injunctive or other appropriate judicial relief for the purpose of enforcing this Part and enjoining or restraining any violations of this Part.

section.heading: Nuclear-free purchasing by City.
section.text: Whenever practicable, and subject to approval by the Board of Estimates, all City departments, agencies, boards, commissions, officers, and employees who purchase or lease goods and services for the City of Baltimore shall make good faith efforts not to contract for, purchase, or lease goods or services produced, sold, distributed, or supplied by manufacturers of nuclear weapons or components.

section.heading: Exclusions.
section.text: Nothing in this Part shall be construed to prohibit:

para.text: any activity not specifically described in this Part;
the use, storage, or treatment and disposal of radioactive materials used in basic academic research, medical research, or the diagnosis and treatment of patients;
consumer uses of radioactive material for smoke detectors, light emitting watches or clocks, industrial radiography and tracer processes, and other similar incidental applications; and
direct activities of the federal government or its employees.

section.heading: Disposal of radioactive materials prohibited.
section.text: Except as specifically exempted in this Part, no person shall incinerate or dispose of radioactive materials, for any purpose, within Baltimore City or within landfills or incinerators owned or licensed by Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Each violation of this Part shall be punishable by a $1,000 fine.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day of violation shall be deemed a separate violation.

section.heading: Exclusions.
section.text: Nothing in this Part shall be construed to prohibit:

para.text: any activity not specifically described in this Part;
the transportation of radioactive materials used in basic academic research, medical research, or the diagnosis and treatment of patients;
consumer uses of radioactive material for smoke detectors, light emitting watches or clocks, industrial radiography and tracer processes, and other similar incidental applications;
direct activities of the federal government or its employees; and
the transportation of radioactive materials to and through the Port of Baltimore.

section.heading: Restrictions on transportation of radioactive materials.

para.heading: Office of Disaster Control to prepare report.
para.text: Within 2 years of the effective date of this Part, the Office of Disaster Control and Civil Defense shall prepare a report for the City Council covering the following areas:
a determination of which existing federal, state, and local laws can be used to control the transportation of radioactive materials;
a survey of shippers and recipients of radioactive materials in or near the municipality;
a consideration of alternative routes to those presently allowed under 49 C.F.R., using DOT guidelines and local safety analyses, and cooperating with state routing agencies where applicable; and
an emergency response plan and assessment of capabilities for accidents involving radioactive materials transport.

para.heading: Notices to Fire Communication Center.
para.text: The Board of Fire Commissioners of Baltimore shall request that state officials notify Baltimore City's Fire Communication Center of the transportation of radioactive materials, based upon the requirements of federal law, 10 C.F.R. 171.97(c)3, which requires shippers to notify the state governor or his designees, no less than 96 hours prior to such shipments.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Carbon offset.
para.text: "Carbon offset" means one metric ton of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) that is kept out of the atmosphere by either:
preventing the creation of the emissions; or
sequestering carbon in:
vegetation;
soils;
rock; or
water.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Planning or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Environmental justice.
para.text: "Environmental justice" means the fair treatment of all individuals regardless of race, color, national origin, or income with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations, and policies.

para.heading: Greenhouse gas.
para.text: "Greenhouse gas" includes carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride.

para.heading: Net-zero emissions.
para.text: "Net-zero emissions" means the balancing of greenhouse gas emissions with emissions off-sets that cause an equivalent reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

para.heading: Office.
para.text: "Office" means the Baltimore City Office of Sustainability.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Baltimore City Office of Sustainability.

para.heading: A Division of Planning.
para.text: The Office is a Division in the Department of Planning.

section.heading: Sustainability Manager.
section.text: The Director of Planning shall employ a Sustainability Manager.

section.heading: Staff and consultants.
section.text: The Director may employ a staff and may contract for consultants and other experts as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: "Sustainable community" defined.
para.text: A sustainable community is one in which economic, ecological, and social well-being are integrated to ensure all live well, within nature's means.
The mission of the Office is to develop and advocate for programs, policies, and actions by government, citizens, and businesses that lead to sustainable communities in the City.
These programs, policies, and actions include those that:
support a diverse and vibrant economy;
promote an equitable distribution of resources;
protect and restore the integrity of the natural systems that support life, including air, water, and land;
preserve the diversity of plant and animal life; and
reduce human impacts on local and worldwide ecosystems.

para.heading: Office to develop.
para.text: The Office shall develop a Sustainability and Environmental Management Program for the City.
The Program shall incorporate the Sustainability Plan developed by the Commission on Sustainability and any other recommendations made by the Commission.
The Program shall include appropriate measures for:
developing, implementing, and coordinating City policies that
make all City operations achieve;
by January 1, 2025, a 30% reduction in greenhouse gas
emissions from 2007 levels;
by January 1, 2030, a 60% reduction in greenhouse gas
emissions from 2007 levels; and
by January 1, 2045, net-zero emissions, as defined in
§ 34-1(f) of this subtitle;
developing or coordinating City policies and programs that will improve environmental performance in City operations;
facilitating the City's compliance with federal, state, and local
environmental regulations;
advancing the City's environmental priorities;
integrating sustainability and environmental values into City plans,
programs, and policies; and
setting sustainability and environmental targets and objectives for the
City.

para.heading: Implementation.
para.text: The Office shall oversee implementation of the Program.

section.heading: Support for other programs and policies.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Office shall seek to assure proper City support for the City's green building, energy policy, and solid waste and recycling programs.

para.heading: Specific duties.
para.text: To this end, the Office shall:
direct and evaluate energy policy and global warming action plan implementation;
administer and monitor direct City government energy efficiency activities;
review City policies and programs for consistency with the policy;
make recommendations to the City Council on the policies and programs; and
administer and monitor programs in support of green building and sustainable development principles.

section.heading: Director's powers and duties – In general.
section.text: The Director shall:

para.text: prepare and update annually a sustainability and environmental management planning agenda for the City;
report to the Mayor and City Council on the performance in meeting sustainability and environmental targets and objectives of:
each City agency; and
the City overall;

serve, in conjunction with other affected agency heads, as the City's representative to boards, commissions, and organizations engaged in issues relating to sustainability and environmental management;
manage the activities, as described in City Code Article 5, Subtitle 34, of the Commission on Sustainability;
regularly review and propose appropriate changes to the Environmental Management Program; and
perform any other duties prescribed by law.

section.heading: Director's powers and duties – Rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: These rules and regulations shall require transparency and community-based public participation mechanisms to provide input to and track the progress of the City's development and implementation of City policies that make all City operations achieve:
by January 1, 2025, a 30% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from 2007 levels;
by January 1, 2030, a 60% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from 2007 levels; and
by January 1, 2045, net-zero emissions, as defined in § 34-1(f) of this subtitle.

section.heading: City Seal - established.
section.text: The seal heretofore provided and used, the impression on which is a representation of the Battle Monument, is hereby established and declared to have been and now to be the Seal of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: Director of Finance to keep.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall take under his charge and keeping the Corporate Seal of the City, and use it in all cases which now are or may hereafter be required, either by the laws of the United States, the several States, the ordinances of this corporation, or the usage and customs of nations, whenever applied to for that purpose.
And for each and every seal which he shall affix to an instrument or instruments of writing, he shall be entitled to receive for the use of the City, the sum of $2.

Except that in cases where the certificate of the Director of Finance under seal shall be required to be used as evidence in the claims of soldiers and seamen in the United States service, or in the claims of the widows or heirs of such as may have died, or may hereafter die in the service, he shall furnish such certificate without any charge whatever.

No person other than the Director of Finance and his clerks and subordinates shall attach, impress, or affix the Corporate Seal of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore to any paper, instrument, or document whatsoever.

No person shall use a copy or facsimile of the Seal of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore for any advertising purposes whatsoever, nor shall a copy or facsimile of said Seal be used in any pamphlet, program, prospectus, or paper or document of any character other than the official publications and stationery of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore and its officers and officials.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of $500 for each offense, said fine to be collected as other fines for the violation of City Ordinances are collected.

section.heading: City Seal - motor vehicles.
section.text: Nothing in this subtitle shall be construed to prevent or affect the use of, by a resident of Baltimore City, a copy or facsimile of the Seal of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, if it is affixed to a motor vehicle where a registration plate is normally placed and if such use is not prohibited by the Motor Vehicle Laws of the State of Maryland.

section.heading: City Slogan.
section.text: The phrase "Baltimore – Birthplace of The Star-Spangled Banner" is established and approved as the official slogan of the City of Baltimore.

section.heading: City Flag.
section.text: The following described design, recommended by the aforesaid legally authorized "Flag Commission" {cf. Ord. 14-507 and Preamble to Ord. 14-565}, is hereby approved and established as the official "Flag of Baltimore City":

para.text: The Flag shall be of the Lord Baltimore colors, to wit, black and gold, heraldically arranged as in his armorial bearings, that is to say, paly of 6 pieces, or, and Sable, a bend counterchanged; and superimposed thereon, as an augmentation of honor, a shield, sable, bordered, or, charged with the Battle Monument argent, in memory of the Defenders of Baltimore during the War of 1812-14.
The said Flag in dimensions, shall be 9 feet long by 6 feet deep (or of the proportions of 3 to 2), the superimposed shield being 2 feet 6 inches wide by 3 feet and 3/8 of an inch from top to tip.

The said Flag in color and in heraldic layout shall be in accordance with design published in the Municipal Journal of December 18, 1914, and now on file in the office of the Department of Legislative Reference.

section.heading: American flag on City buildings.
section.text: The superintendent of any of the public buildings belonging to and used by the municipal government of the City shall cause to be raised the American flag on the same:

para.text: on each and every legal holiday during the year; and
at half-mast on May 30 (known as Memorial Day).

section.heading: Baltimore Day.
section.text: August 8 of each year shall be Baltimore Day in honor of Baltimore's founding on August 8, 1729. The Mayor annually shall proclaim this day as Baltimore Day, to recognize this important moment in the City's history.

section.heading: Henrietta Lacks Day.
section.text: August 1 of each year shall be Henrietta Lacks Day in honor of the birth on August 1, 1920 of Henrietta Lacks, whose cervical cancer cells were taken without her or her family's knowledge or consent to create the HeLa line of cells used to further medical science, including cures and treatments for diseases such as polio, cancer, and AIDS. The Mayor annually shall proclaim this day as Henrietta Lacks Day to recognize this important moment in medical history.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to other legal holidays established from time to time by union contract, by agency regulation, or by action of the Board of Estimates, the following days are legal holidays for the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Indigenous Peoples' Day.
para.text: Indigenous Peoples' Day, the second Monday in October of each year.

section.heading: Observance.
section.text: The City shall observe the legal holidays specified in § 36A-1 of this subtitle annually, in the same manner as it observes other legal holidays established from time to time by union contract, by agency regulation, or by action of the Board of Estimates.

section.heading: Discount on City services, permits, and equipment costs for nonprofit events.

para.heading: Required discount.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, if an event is open to the public without charge and sponsored by a qualifying organization described in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the fees for City services, permits, or equipment used to support the event must be reduced by 50% from the otherwise applicable rates.
An organization qualifies for the 50% discount required by paragraph (1) of this subsection if it is:
a nonprofit, tax-exempt charitable or religious organization; or
an organization that is not required to pay any federal, state, or local taxes.
Organizations eligible for the 50% discount required by paragraph (1) of this subsection include:
the Mayor's Office of Minority and Women-Owned Business Development's Main Street programs;
Retail Business District Business Associations established under City Code Article 14, § 11-9 {"Business Associations"};
Business Improvement Districts;
Community associations, neighborhood organizations, homeowners' associations, and organized block clubs; and
sports organizations with 15 or more Baltimore City youth aged 18 years old or younger as participants.

para.heading: Documentation to be provided.
para.text: The sponsoring organization must submit satisfactory evidence to the Director of Transportation, or the Director's designee, documenting its qualifications for the discount provided by this section at the time that it requests City services, permits, or equipment for its event.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: The following types of events are not eligible for the 50% discount required by this section:
pub crawls; and
road races.

section.heading: Fees ineligible for discount.
section.text: The 50% discount required by this subtitle does not apply to:

para.text: the fee schedule of the Department of Recreation and Parks;
fees imposed by the Parking Authority;
fees charged by the Department of Housing and Community Development for temporary structures pursuant to Building Code § 109.6.1m {"Temporary structures"}; or
fees charged by the Fire Department.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.
